00001 #ifndef TREESTREAM_HPP
00002 #define TREESTREAM_HPP
00003 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------
00004 // File: treestream.hpp
00005 //
00006 // Description: The classes itreestream and otreestream provide a convenient 
00007 //              interface to the kind of Root trees typically used in HEP
00008 //              analyses. Our (default) assumption is that there is one tree 
00009 //              per Root file and the objects stored are simple types. The
00010 //              treestream classes hide the boilerplate code for getting at 
00011 //              the tree, its branches and leaves.
00012 //
00013 //              The design is based on the observation that, ultimately, data
00014 //              reduce to a set of name/value pairs in which the value 
00015 //              can be regarded as a homogeneous sequence of doubles, floats 
00016 //              longs, or ints. Moreover, an arbitrarily complex graph of the 
00017 //              name/value pairs is readily achieved with, well, name/value 
00018 //              pairs! Name/value pair is just another name for variable.
00019 // 
00020 //              Thinking in terms of objects, in the context of high energy 
00021 //              physics analysis, has yielded undue complexity. On the other 
00022 //              hand, thinking in terms of name/value pairs reduces the 
00023 //              complexity considerably. The irreducible complexity, which 
00024 //              surely exists, properly resides in the graph generated by 
00025 //              the set of name/value pairs, that is, variables.
00026 //
00027 //              Of course, it is often convenient to package name/value pairs 
00028 //              into objects to avail oneself of their useful behaviour. This 
00029 //              may be useful, for example, to model a particularly 
00030 //              complicated sub-graph of name/value pairs. Or it may be that
00031 //              one wishes to take advantage of an object that defines
00032 //              useful functions on the name/value pairs. A  nice example of 
00033 //              packaging name/value pairs for this reason is the packaging 
00034 //              of the name/value pairs, Px, Py, Pz and E into 
00035 //              HepLorentzVector objects to take advantage of the host of 
00036 //              useful mathematical operations these objects define on them.
00037 //
00038 // Created: 19-Feb-2005 Harrison B. Prosper, based on 12-Mar-2001 version of
00039 //                      the same.
00040 //          14-Jul-2005 Allow for arrays
00041 //          13-Aug-2005 Tidy up
00042 //          11-Aug-2007 Add ls() method as a proxy for print
00043 //          06-Jun-2010 Add store and save (commt = store + save)
00044 //$Revision: 1.8 $
00045 //----------------------------------------------------------------------------

00065 struct Field
00066 {
00067   Field() : srctype(' '),
00068             iotype(' '),
00069             isvector(false),
00070             iscounter(false),
00071             maxsize(0),
00072             branch(0),
00073             leaf(0),
00074             address(0),
00075             branchname(""),
00076             leafname("") {}
00077   
00078   virtual ~Field() {}
00079   
00080   char   srctype;         
00081   char   iotype;          
00082   bool   isvector;        
00083   bool   iscounter;       
00084   int    maxsize;         
00085   
00086   TBranch* branch;        
00087   TLeaf*   leaf;          
00088   void*    address;       
00089   
00090   std::string branchname; 
00091   std::string leafname;   
00092 };
00093 
00094 template <class T>
00095 struct FieldBuffer : public Field
00096 {
00097   FieldBuffer() : Field(), value(std::vector<T>()) {}
00098   virtual ~FieldBuffer() {}
00099   
00100   std::vector<T> value;
00101 };
00102 
00103 typedef std::map<std::string, Field>  Data;
00104 typedef std::map<std::string, Field*> SelectedData;
